Project Description

The  Project  will  help  improve  access  to  basic  urban  infrastructure
and essential municipal services in about 40 urban local government
units  (LGUs)  throughout  Mindanao.  It  will  be  driven  by  the  demand
and needs of LGUs that now lack urban infrastructure and municipal
services  needed  for  urban  development.  LGUs  that  meet  the
selection  criteria  will  be  eligible  for  subproject  financing  from  LBP.
The  Project  also  aims  to  improve  the  institutional  capacity  of
participating LGUs to provide, operate, and maintain essential urban
infrastructure services.

The  high  rate  of  urban  growth  in  the  Philippines  combined  with
inadequate  local  investments  has  led  to  serious  deficiencies  in  the
provision  of  basic  urban  infrastructure  and  municipal  services,
particularly in Mindanao. Despite its abundant natural resources and
fertile  soil,  Mindanao  is  among  the  poorest  regions  in  the  country.
The  incidence  of  urban  poverty  is  nearly  twice  the  national  urban
average,  and  the  provision  of  municipal  services  is  well  below  the
national average. The institutional capacity of LGUs in Mindanao to
undertake  their  devolved  functions  and  deliver  adequate  municipal
services  varies  widely.  Because  of  prolonged  civil  strife  and  partly
because of high urbanization coupled with low institutional capacity,
LGUs  can  hardly  meet  the  demand  for  basic  urban  services.
Consequently,  there  is  an  urgent  need  to  improve  urban  service
delivery  by  (i)  upgrading  and  expanding  infrastructure,  and  (ii)
improving  the  capability  and  capacity  of  LGUs  to  provide  and
manage  services.  Improved  basic  urban  services  will  help  reduce
poverty  and  raise  living  standards,  strengthen  links  between  urban
and rural areas, and support the peace process.

 I.

THE PROPOSAL

1.
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  Report  and  Recommendation  on  a  proposed
loan  to  the  Land  Bank  of  the  Philippines  (LBP),  to  be  guaranteed  by  the  Republic  of  the
Philippines, for the Mindanao Basic Urban Services Sector Project.

II.

INTRODUCTION

2.
In  1998,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  project  preparatory  technical
assistance (TA)1 to formulate a Project to improve the access of Mindanao’s urban residents to
municipal infrastructure and services. The TA, completed in May 1999, identified the scope for
infrastructure  investments  in  Mindanao  and  the  capacity-building  needs  of  local  government
units (LGUs).2 The TA also covered feasibility studies for pilot LGUs. The proposed Project was
formulated on the basis of a sample of 13 LGUs. Subprojects were prepared for three LGUs and
detailed  feasibility  studies  were  made  for  five  representative  components.  The  Loan  Fact-
Finding Mission was undertaken intermittently from June to December 1999, and LBP confirmed
its  willingness  to  cofinance  the  proposed  Project.  Following  consultations  with  pilot  LGUs
through  workshops,  and  the  Government’s  endorsement,  an  Appraisal  Mission3  visited
Mindanao  in  September  2000  and  held  discussions  with  key  Government  officials  and
representatives of LBP, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and potential beneficiaries. The
Mission  reached  an  understanding  with  Government  and  LBP  on  the  project  concept,  scope,
cost, financing, implementation arrangements, capacity-building components, and policy action
agenda.  This  report  is  based  on  those  discussions  and  the  reports  prepared  by  the  TA
consultants. The project framework is shown in Appendix 1.

III.

BACKGROUND

A.

Sector Description

1. 

Urbanization and Demand for Infrastructure

3.
The Philippines has a population of about 75 million, of which 52 percent, or 39 million,
is urban.4 Although the national population growth rate slowed from 3.0 percent to 2.3 percent
per year between 1960 and 2000, the urban population grew at an average annual rate of more
than 5 percent over the same period. The urban population increased from 8 million in 1960 to
39  million  in  2000.  By  2010,  the  Philippines  is  expected  to  have  about  90  million  people,  60
percent (54 million) of them living in the urban areas.

4.
The  fast  growth  in  the  urban  population  has  resulted  in  a  substantial  backlog  in  the
delivery of urban services. Despite gradual improvements, only about 60 percent of those living
in  urban  areas  have  access  to  household  water  supply,  and  almost  none  have  access  to
sewerage  systems.  Almost  40  percent  of  solid  waste  remains  uncollected  or  is  thrown  into
unsanitary open dump sites. Traffic congestion is common as there is only 1 kilometer (km) of
urban  roads  for  every  1,800  people.  Every  year,  flooding  occurs  due  to  inadequate  drainage
and  flood  protection  facilities.  This  causes  damage  to  property  and  loss  of  human  lives.5
Insufficient and unsanitary facilities in public markets, which are usually located at town centers,
inhibit productive economic activities and threaten public health.

5.
The Philippines faces the difficult task of providing and maintaining an adequate level of
basic  infrastructure  and  municipal  services.  Rapid  urbanization  continues  to  place  enormous
pressure  on  government  institutions,  which  must  supply  the  urban  services  needed  to  sustain
economic growth and to improve the quality of life. The poor urban communities in particular are
disadvantaged by the high level of service deprivation and environmental degradation.

2. 

Urban Poverty

About  eight  million  urban  people,  or  21.5  percent  of  the  urban  population6  in  the
6.
Philippines,  live  below  the  poverty  line,  which  is  defined  as  a  minimum  yearly  income  of
P12,577 per person.7 Most urban poor live in a blighted environment, with little or no access to
basic  urban  infrastructure  and  services,  sanitation,  capital  assets  or  financial  sources,  and
employment  and  livelihood  opportunities.  If  unmeasured  deprivation  of  access  to  basic
infrastructure services as well as unaccounted-for informal settlers were taken into account, at
least one third of the urban population would be considered urban poor.8 Though the incidence
of  poverty  in  urban  areas  is  lower  than  the  national  average  (37.5  percent  of  population),  the
uneven concentration of poverty and poor living conditions in urban areas makes urban poverty
relatively harsher than rural poverty. Urban poverty statistics based on income data alone do not
capture the dire living conditions of the urban poor, and urban poverty has been recognized as a
key sector issue9 that must be urgently addressed.

3.

Sector Institutions

The passage of the Local Government Code (LGC) in 1991 triggered decentralization of
7.
authority  and  responsibilities  for  financing,  managing,  and  developing  urban  areas  from  the
national  Government  to  LGUs.  The  national  Government  retains  responsibility  for  policy  and
strategy formulation, legislative and regulatory control, advisory services, and capital investment
in  national  infrastructure.  Because  urban  development  is  a  complex  process,  several
departments and agencies are involved in the urban sector. At the central level, the Department
of  the  Interior  and  Local  Government  (DILG)  is  mandated  to  guide  and  strengthen  the
administrative performance of LGUs. The Department of Finance (DOF) and the Department of
Budget  and  Management  (DBM)  are  responsible  for  fiscal  management,  resource  allocation,
and  budget  sharing  between  the  national  and  local  governments.  The  National  Economic  and
Development Authority (NEDA) makes national and regional plans, and the Housing and Urban
Development Coordinating Council (HUDCC) formulates urban sector policy. The Department of
Public  Works  and  Highways  (DPWH)  carries  out  national  physical  infrastructure  development

At  the  regional  level,  the  regional  development  councils  facilitate  intragovernment

regional and field offices (province, city, and municipal) are the extension arms of the DILG for
supervising and monitoring local government functions and implementation of national programs
by LGUs. DILG has strong vertical links to maintain dialogue with LGUs at all levels. DILG has
not yet operationalized any means to assess the operations, performance, and governance of
LGUs and to promote their managerial and technical productivity.

At  city  and  municipal  levels,  LGUs  are  classified  into  six  income  classes  according  to
9.
their revenue, land area, and population, with class I LGUs having the highest income and class
VI  the  lowest.  The  first  class  cities  and  municipalities  should  have  had  an  average  annual

regardless  of  income,  are  expected  to  provide  the  local  infrastructure  and  municipal  services
needed by residents. LGUs need to be self-reliant to finance essential urban infrastructure and
services, such as water supply,10 sanitation, drainage, flood control, solid waste management,
municipal  roads,  bridges,  public  markets,  transport  terminals,  and  other  municipal  enterprise
facilities.

4.

LGU Finances

10.
About  two  thirds  of  LGU  revenues  come  from  the  internal  revenue  allotment  (IRA)
provided by the national Government, and the remaining third from local taxes and other local
revenues.  With  their  substantial  reliance  on  the  national  budget  and  expanded  taxing  powers
under the LGC, LGUs are expected to set aside 20 percent of their IRA for local development
funds.

Apart from the IRA, LGUs may avail themselves of debt financing for investment capital
11.
from the Municipal Development Fund (MDF), government financial institutions (GFIs) such as
LBP and Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP), or private banks (primarily the Philippine
National Bank, which was a GFI until its recent privatization). The development funds from IRA
can  be  a  significant  source  of  cash  flows  that  can  be  tapped  into  for  the  long-term  capital
required  for  infrastructure  development.  However,  many  lower  class  LGUs  have  underutilized
borrowing  capacity  and  are  constrained  in  delivering  basic  services  because  of  lack  of
investment  capital.  In  general,  private  banks  are  reluctant  to  lend  to  LGUs  mainly  because  (i)
the banks have no access to information on the financial status of LGUs, (ii) LGUs do not have
deposits at hand to serve as collateral, and (iii) the banks do not specialize in term lending for
capital  investment.  GFIs,  which  are  the  authorized  depository  banks  for  LGUs,  therefore  have

an  edge  over  private  banks  when  it  comes  to  lending  to  LGUs.  Though  the  GFIs  can  use  the
LGUs’  deposits  or  scheduled  deposits  (such  as  IRA  funds)  as  collateral,  their  resources  are
limited  to  short-term  lending.  LGUs  also  do  not  have  direct  access  to  official  development

For  their  financing  needs,  lower-income  LGUs  rely  mostly  on  the  MDF,11  which  has  a  rigid
application  and  approval  process.  Underresourced  LGUs  must  be  given  more  access  to  and
information about financial intermediaries for their long-term capital needs.

12. While LGUs have taxation authority under the LGC, lack of experience among their staff,
lack  of  political  will,  and  inefficiencies  in  fiscal  management  have  generally  kept  them  from
exercising such authority effectively. Lower-income LGUs tend to rely more on the IRA portion
(up  to  90  percent  of  annual  revenues)  than  higher-income  LGUs  do  (35  percent  for  highly
urbanized  cities),  and  thus  have  low  capital  reserves.  LGUs  are  more  likely  to  generate
revenues  from  municipal  enterprises  rather  than  from  improvements  in  the  tax  base  through
strategic  financial  planning  and  fiscal  management.  Lower-income  LGUs  (those  between
classes  III  and  VI)  have  relatively  weak  financial  management  capability  and  cannot  meet  the
growing demand for better services. The imbalance calls for an improved tax basis and active
lending  by  creditors.  Comprehensive  capability  and  capacity  building  is  needed  to  promote
balanced growth and to help underresourced LGUs improve their capacity to function properly
and thus achieve efficient decentralization.

5.

Mindanao

13.
Mindanao is composed of five administrative regions (IX, X, XI, XII, CARAGA), and the
Autonomous  Region of Muslim Mindanao (ARMM), with a total of 24 provinces, 19 cities, and
about 408  urban and rural municipalities. Of the 17 million people living in Mindanao, about 6
million (35 percent) are classified as urban dwellers. Mindanao is lagging behind the rest of the
country economically: over one third of its labor force is unemployed or underemployed, and per
capita income is only 75 percent of the national average. The Mindanao urban sector accounts
for only about 50 percent of gross regional product for the region, lower than the proportion of
the urban sector as a whole in the national economy (about 80 percent).

14.
Deficiencies  in  urban  infrastructure  and  service  levels  in  Mindanao  are  higher  than  the
national  average.  For  example,  the  incidence  of  the  use  of  drinking  water  from  potentially
polluted sources is 24 percent in urban Mindanao, compared with 12 percent in the Philippines
as a whole. Similarly, whereas almost 80 percent of households in the urban Philippines have
access to water-sealed toilets, only 60 percent of households in Mindanao enjoy such facilities.
The inadequacies in basic infrastructure services in Mindanao are due partly to the difficulty of
access to capital markets and partly to the weak technical, institutional, and financial capacity of
the  LGUs  in  the  region.  The  National  Anti-Poverty  Commission,  in  its  National  Anti-Poverty
Agenda  2000,  states  that  measures  for  strengthening  institutional  capacity  are  fundamental  to
addressing poverty reduction.

15.

Mindanao had the highest incidence of poverty in its urban areas (37 percent). The incidence of
poverty was highest (51 percent) in the urban areas of ARMM and lowest in the urban areas of
regions IX (26 percent) and XI (27 percent), respectively, but the two latter regions had a higher

A.

Rationale

1. 

Project Rationale

Urban growth in the Philippines has outpaced the provision of basic urban infrastructure
38.
and  services,  adversely  affecting  the  quality  of  life  and  the  environment.  LGUs,  with
responsibility for urban development are hard pressed to meet the rapid increase in the demand
for  municipal  services.  The  urban  poor,  in  particular,  do  not  have  adequate  access  to  basic
services and facilities. A comprehensive and sustainable solution to the problem of inadequate
basic urban infrastructure is, therefore, urgently needed.

39.
Mindanao, the Philippines’ second largest island, is often referred to as the food basket
of the country because of its rich natural resources. But peace and order problems have slowed
its  development.  Compared  with  the  rest  of  the  country,  urban  poverty  is  more  widespread,
income  per  capita  is  lower,  and  the  urban  areas  offer  even  less  coverage  of  municipal
infrastructure  and  basic  services.  Existing  disparities  within  Mindanao  also  hamper  equitable
growth. The 1996 Peace Agreement and the associated creation of SZOPAD were intended to
speed up development in areas racked by civil strife. Only limited success has been achieved,
however, partly because of low access to the capital markets and lack of opportunities for local
governments to initiate and implement development programs. The proposed Project supports
the Government’s peace and development framework, and its efforts to rehabilitate urban areas
in Mindanao and to promote equitable development in the country.

Economic and Financial Analyses

1. 

Approach

86.
Economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) were computed for all components. Cash flow
projections and financial internal rates of return (FIRRs) were calculated for revenue-generating
components for which costs are expected to be recovered directly from user charges, fees, and
tariffs.  A  sensitivity  analysis  was  also  done.  The  domestic  price  numeraire  was  used  in  the
economic evaluation because project outputs are mainly nontradable. For valuation of tradable
goods,  a  shadow  exchange  rate  factor  of  1.22,  based  on  the  standard  conversion  factor  of
0.837, was used. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.7 was applied to the wage of unskilled labor at
the domestic price level.

The financial evaluation of revenue-generating components examined the degree of cost
87.
recovery  from  the  investments  and,  hence,  the  financial  sustainability  of  those  investments.
Capital expenditures (land, civil works, equipment, detailed engineering design and construction
supervision,  and  resettlement  costs)  were  assumed  to  coincide  with  the  life  cycle  costs  and
revenues  of  the  subproject.  Revenues  were  estimated  on  the  basis  of  the  proposed  user
charges for the new and improved facilities. In principle, user charges were set at a level that
would  cover  all  operation  and  maintenance  costs  plus  the  financial  costs  of  the  project
component.  Prices  (tariffs)  are  expected  to  increase  over  time  to  keep  up  with  rising  costs
(inflation) and allow the proper operation of the proposed facilities over the life of the asset.

C.

Impact on Poverty

Poverty  incidence  in  urban  Mindanao  is  at  least  15  percent  higher  than  the  national
97.
average. The Project is designed to reduce regional development gap, and to promote equitable
growth  of  Mindanao  by  targeting  urban  LGUs.  Attention  has  been  given  to  improve  the  living
conditions  of  the  poor  and  in  the  LGUs  with  limited  local  resources.  Improving  urban
infrastructure and related services will not only enhance the productivity of urban economy but
also  benefit  the  poor  by  improving  their  living  standards,  and  by  providing  employment
opportunities. Improvement of roads, bridges, or public markets that everybody can access will
generally enhance the productivity of urban economic activities. A positive distributional effect to
the  urban  poor  is  expected.  The  urban  poor  will  also  benefit  directly  from  a  number  of
subprojects. For example, civil works of subprojects will hire unskilled laborers for construction,
and  provide  employment  and  income-earning  opportunities  for  the  poor;  or  the  water  supply
project  will  substantially  bring  down  household  expenses  spent  for  water  vendors  as  well  as
time spent in fetching water, resulting in real income savings for the poor.

98.
Under the sector approach, about 40 LGUs (or about 2 million population) are expected
to  receive benefits of the Project. More than 40 percent of beneficiaries fall below the poverty
line.  It  is  expected  that  about  0.8  million  beneficiaries  will  be  the  urban  poor.  However,  the
distributional  impact  on  poverty  will  vary  depending  on  the  numbers  and  investment  size  of
subproject  components  across  subsectors.  Overall,  the  increased  employment  and  income-
earning opportunities during project implementation will be one of the substantial benefits to the
poor.  It  is  estimated  that  about  100,000  person-months  of  employment  opportunities  will  be
generated.  Analysis  of  the  socioeconomic  survey  demonstrates  wide  distribution  of  benefits
from the subprojects throughout the project areas. The Project impact on poverty is presented in
Appendix 15.

99.
However,  ensuring  equitable  access  of  the  urban  poor  communities  to  improved
services  is  a  major  social  challenge.  To  address  this,  the  proposed  Project  includes  direct
intervention and indirect incentive mechanisms to bring urban services for the poor. For direct
intervention, subprojects are required to adopt direct participation and representation of the poor
through  a  community  participatory  planning  approach  when  the  LGU  prioritizes  investment
needs.  Indirect  incentive  mechanism  is  included  as  up  to  25  percent  of  grant  financing  for  a
component  such  as  sanitation,  drainage,  and  flood  protection  measures,  from  which  the  poor
living  in  flood-prone  areas  will  benefit  significantly.  The  grant  financing  from  the  Government
provides  incentives  for  low-income  LGUs  to  invest  in  a  nonrevenue-generating  component  for
positive environmental and distributional benefits from infrastructure services.

D.

Social Dimensions

100. Appendix 15 outlines social impact assessment. The proposed Project provides for basic
infrastructure  such  as  roads,  markets,  water  supply,  drainage  or  other  social  infrastructure
services  to  support  the  overall  level  of  economic  and  social  well  being.  The  levels  of
infrastructure services in the targeted LGUs are lower than the National average. Therefore, the
Project serves both short- and long-term development needs. In addition, the proposed Project
will  have  a  direct  as  well  as  an  indirect  impact  on  employment  and  income  generation.  The
construction  of  most  of  the  basic  urban  infrastructure  and  services  will  be  labor-intensive  and
will require low-skilled workers who can come from the ranks of the urban poor. Bus terminals
and  roads  will  improve  access  to  economic  centers  in  towns  with  public  markets  and
slaughterhouses.

Improving  the  provision  of  water  supply,  sanitation,  roads,  solid  waste  disposal,  and
101.
other  infrastructure  will  also  lead  to  better  health,  enhance  the  quality  of  life,  and  save  time.
People living in communities that will be supplied with water facilities for the first time will spend
less time transporting water. The time they save can be used in other activities. Women, who
together with children suffer most from poor living conditions in urban areas, are not the specific
targets  of  the  Project,  but  they  will  benefit  from  improved  living  conditions  as  a  result  of
improved  infrastructure.  Gender  considerations  are  built  into  the  Project  to  equalize  access  to
the  benefits  from  poverty  reduction  and  employment  creation,  and  to  ensure  that  project
planning and implementation take the needs of the whole community into account.

E.

Environment

102. Subprojects  will  have  a  positive  environmental  impact.  They  will  repair,  upgrade,  or
replace  failing  or  inadequate  infrastructure  and  public  facilities,  and  will  therefore  improve
health,  quality  of  life,  sanitation,  and  environmental  conditions.  Five  components  in  three  pilot
core LGUs were selected for environmental assessment: (i) the Miputak-Torne bypass road and
foreshore development in Dipolog, (ii) the water supply and distribution upgrade in Parang, and
(iii)  bus  and  jeepney  terminal  and  solid  waste  disposal  facilities  in  Kidapawan.  Initial
environmental  examinations,  prepared  for  each  of  the  subprojects  in  the  three  pilot  LGUs,47
revealed  that  none  of  the  pilot  subprojects  were  located  in  an  environmentally  sensitive  area,
and any adverse environmental effects would be minor and easily mitigated.

F.

Risks

103. Risks that could affect the overall success of the Project have been identified. The main
risk  comes  from  the  civil  strife  in  Mindanao.  The  Peace  Agreement  signed  in  1996  is  a
significant  step  in  the  long  peace  process,  and  has  led  to  significantly  improved  peace  and
order. However, sporadic conflicts still occur in the rural areas. The safety issue may therefore
make inspection of progress difficult in some of the subproject areas - as land travel through the
rural area would be risky–and, to some extent, affect project implementation.

104. Other project risks include potential lack of interest among LGUs in participating in the
Project;  lower  than  expected  LGU  financial  resources;  implementation  delays,  particularly  at
start-up, due to delay in creating PIUs, or in recruiting consultants; shortcomings in subproject
preparation  and  appraisal  that  could  reduce  the  desired  socioeconomic  benefits;  lack  of
commitment to institutional development; and continued shortage of services for the poor. Also,
a  subproject  started  under  one  mayor  of  an  LGU  may  not  necessarily  be  completed  by  the
subsequent mayor.

105.
To  minimize  these  risks,  the  design  and  implementation  arrangements  for  the  Project
have  the  following  features:  (i)  a  modest-size  Project  has  been  formulated  to  minimize  the
financial  burden  on  the  national  Government  and  LGUs;  (ii)  a  consultant  recruited  directly  by
DILG  with  NDF  finance  will  assist  in  starting  up  the  Project  and  setting  up  project
implementation units; (iii) advance action for hiring consultants is in place; (iv) to participate in
the  Project,  LGUs  must  contribute  equity  and  counterpart  funds  and  be  committed  to
institutional  strengthening;  (v)  consultants  will  help  prepare  and  strengthen  subprojects;  (vi)
communities  will  take  part  in  designing  subprojects;  and  (vii)  to  reduce  the  risks  of  political

LGUs  also  revealed  a  very  high  preference  (81  percent)  for  improved  sanitation  services.
Willingness to pay for sanitation services is correspondingly high. Responses varied with regard
to patterns of solid waste collection in the pilot areas. In Parang, where there is low satisfaction
with  current  waste  collection,  there  is  a  high  willingness  to  pay.  In  Kidapawan,  on  the  other
hand, low satisfaction is not matched by a high willingness to pay. In Dipolog, the majority of the
surveyed  population  is  satisfied  with  links  to  the  provinces,  Mindanao,  and  the  rest  of  the
Philippines.  The  survey  asked  people  to  identify  public  buildings  and  facilities  that  they  would
consider  priority  areas  for  improvement.  In  the  entire  pilot  LGUs,  improvement  to  the  public
market is the main area of concern. Other significant choices for improvement are the intercity
bus terminal, main bus terminal, sea transport terminal, and sports center.

D.

Participation of Community and Nongovernment Organizations

Subproject  components  are  identified  through  public  consultations,  workshops,  and
11.
seminars  with  extensive  stakeholder  participation.  The  LGU  decision  on  the  selection  and
prioritization  of  components  was  also  carried  out  in  a  participatory  manner,  involving  relevant
stakeholders,  particularly  the  poor,  women,  and  local  civic  organizations.  A  community-based
participatory  approach  to  project  planning  and  implementation,  which  is  built  on  community
priority needs, will in general both maximize positive impacts and minimize negative impacts.

E. 

Urban Services for the Poor

12.
As  over  40  percent  of  poverty  incidence  is  common  and  wide  spread  in  LGUs  in
Mindanao,  most  subproject  interventions  will  serve  the  urban  poor  substantially  in  both  direct
and  indirect  ways.  The  proposed  Project  includes  direct  intervention  and  indirect  incentive
mechanisms  to  provide  urban  services  for  the  poor,  such  as  (i)  direct  participation  and
representation  of  the  poor  in  a  community  participatory  planning  approach  for  prioritizing
investment  needs;  (ii)  up  to  25  percent  of  grant  financing  for  subproject  components  such  as
sanitation,  drainage,  and  flood  protection  measures,  from  which  the  poor  living  in  flood-prone
areas  would  benefit  significantly;  and  (iii)  priority  to  the  poor  in  hiring  laborers  in  construction
activities.  Other  components  will  indirectly  benefit  the  poor.  Improving  LGU-wide  infrastructure
services and the urban environment will enhance the general well-being and the quality of life
for poor communities.

F.

Potential Beneficiaries and Poverty Impact

13.
The  economic  impact  of  the  Project  has  been  identified  as  more  employment
opportunities and improved quality of living standards. The impact of the Project on poverty will
vary  with  the  individual  components  proposed  and  executed  by  LGUs.  Most  of  the  subproject
components will directly benefit the primary beneficiaries and indirectly benefit the entire urban
population of the LGU concerned.

The  total  population  of  the  urban  areas  in  the  108  LGUs  eligible  to  participate  in  the
14.
Project is estimated to be about 5 million. The total number of potential beneficiaries would be
about 2 million people, projecting about 40 percent LGUs participating in the Project. However,
not all of the 2 million would benefit to the same extent. The coverage of the project impact very
much depends on individual components selected according to demand, as the Project adopted
a  sector  approach.  Since  urban  infrastructure  and  services  are  for  public  use  (except  water
supply  charging  fees  for  private  connection),  people  from  the  peri-urban  areas  as  well  as  the
residents  of  the  participating  LGUs  would  benefit.  Among  them,  more  than  one  third  (or  0.8
million) of the beneficiaries are expected to be urban poor.

15.
Based on the infrastructure demand revealed by the indicative 13 LGUs, it is estimated
that the distribution of infrastructure investment would be (i) about 27 percent for public markets

and bus terminals, (ii) about 23 percent for roads and bridges, (iii) 14 percent for improvement
of solid waste management, (iv) 6 percent for flood protection and sanitation, (v) 12 percent for
water supply, and (vi) about 18 percent for other public facilities.  Based on the analysis of three
core  pilot  subprojects,  the  needs  to  hire  low-skill  laborers  for  construction  activities  will  be
almost  20  percent  of  all  civil  works.  It  is  estimated  that  the  Project  will  generate  over  100,000
person-months of employment opportunities for the poor. Taking into account the distribution of
physical investment across subsectors, it is estimated that the Project will provide (i) better bus
terminals  and  public  market  facilities  for  over  220,000  poor  people,  (ii)  improved  roads  and
accessibility  for  at  least  190,000  poor  people;  (iii)  improved  solid  waste  collection  for  about
110,000  urban  poor,  (iv)  flood  protection  and  improved  sanitation  facilities  for  about  50,000
poor, (v) affordable water systems for 100,000 poor people, and (v) other public facilities to raise
the living standards of 140,000 poor.
